articles.title: Kamloops smashes nearly 90-year-old daytime temperature record
articles.author: Aaron Schulze
articles.summary: The daily high temperature in Kamloops on Wednesday (Sept. 17) was 34.1 C, breaking the previous record of 32.2 C set back in 1937. The weather agency credits the heat to a strong ridge of high pressure that's bringing unseasonably high temperatures across B.C. in September.

articles.title: Labor's New Emissions Target Criticized: ‘Unlikely to Satisfy Everyone'
articles.author: Internewscast
articles.summary: The federal government revises its 2035 emissions reduction target for Australia. Opposition leader Sussan Ley criticizes it for not detailing the financial impact of achieving a 62 to 70 per cent reduction relative to 2005 levels. Experts and climate action advocates widely condemn the target as inadequate.

articles.title: Reindeer Bring A Gift Greater Than Any Of Santa's – Hope Of A Stable Climate
articles.author: Stephen Luntz
articles.summary: Deep snows prevent the release of carbon dioxide from boreal forests, but when the snows are shallower it can escape. Reindeer and their wild counterparts caribou greatly reduce this problem, provided they are allowed to graze freely. Since they capture half of the carbon dioxide absorbed on land, they're key to climate stability.

articles.title: The Trump Administration Is Dismantling Climate Policies
articles.author: New York Times
articles.summary: The Trump administration flatly denies the threat of global warming, which used to be downplayed, but now it denies the science. It's a shift from downplaying the threat to denying the reality of the threat.    .   "The president does not believe in global warming."

articles.title: Australia sets 62% emissions cut by 2035 amid climate warnings
articles.author: Bangla News24.com
articles.summary: Australia has announced a significant increase in its emissions reduction target, pledging to cut greenhouse gas emissions by at least 62% below 2005 levels by 2035. This is a substantial rise from the previous 2030 goal of 43%. It is part of Australia's obligations under the 2015 Paris Climate Agreement, which aims to limit global temperature rise to 1.5°C to avert the worst effects of climate change.

articles.title: ‘Antidote to despair': Coalition of organizations host climate action event in Georgetown Saturday
articles.author: Christian Collington
articles.summary: Georgetown will host a National Day of Climate Action on Saturday, Sept. 20, from 2 to 4:30 p.m. at St. George's Anglican Church. Halton Hills Climate Action, Seniors for Climate and Grandmothers Act to Save the Planet are co-hosting the event.

articles.title: Region steel mills emit 25m tons of carbon
articles.author: The Times
articles.summary: The Calumet Region's integrated steel mills emit 25 million metric tons of greenhouse gases a year, according to a study found.    .   i   in the study found that they emit more than 25 million tonnes of CO2 a year.

articles.title: Rainforests: From Climate Saviors to Carbon Emitters?
articles.author: Devdiscourse News Desk
articles.summary: Tropical rainforests may contribute to global warming by emitting significant volumes of carbon dioxide. The study evaluated soil respiration rates in a Puerto Rican rainforest subjected to a global temperature rise of 4 degrees Celsius. It found that respiration rate rose by 42-204% in warmed areas compared to ambient ones.

articles.title: 2024 marks third consecutive year of significant ice loss in all glacier regions — UN
articles.author: TASS
articles.summary: Last year, 2024, was the third consecutive year with large-scale ice loss in all glacier regions. The volume lost was equivalent to a 1.2 mm rise in sea level. Record ice mass loss was recorded in Scandinavia, the Svalbard archipelago, and Northern Asia.

articles.title: Summer is lingering longer in WA, new study says. How many more days of heat?
articles.author: Sara Schilling
articles.summary: Summer-like temperatures in many U.S. cities are getting longer because of climate change. Seattle, Spokane and Yakima in Washington are seeing summer-like weather longer. Miami and San Angelo, Texas, have the longest summer, while Florida and New York have the shortest.

articles.title: Australia targets at least 62% emissions cut in the next decade
articles.summary: Australia aims to cut its carbon emissions by at least 62% over the next decade. Climate activists warn the target is not ambitious enough, however. Australia is one of the world's biggest polluters per capita and is one the biggest emitters of CO2.

articles.title: "This Is Climate Armageddon": Atlantic Ocean Current Could Collapse Within Decades And Destroy Europe Forever
articles.author: Avi Cohen
articles.summary: The Atlantic meridional overturning circulation (Amoc) is at its weakest in 1,600 years due to climate change. The Amoc is responsible for transporting warm tropical waters from the tropics to the Arctic and Europe. Without the Amoc, western Europe could experience severe winters and summer droughts. An Amoc shutdown would contribute to rising sea levels, adding 1.6 feet to the current projections.

articles.title: How vulnerable are Australia's cities to extreme heat? Explore our maps
articles.author: The Guardian
articles.summary: Residents of western Sydney and outer suburbs of Melbourne are at risk of high temperatures, according to data from the Australian Bureau of Meteorology's data collection. The data is exclusive and based on data collected by the BPM's data gathering system.

articles.title: The Gout Race: A Growing Challenge in Australia
articles.author: Coin Fellowship
articles.summary: Gout is an inflammatory arthritis characterized by sudden and severe pain in the joints. There has been a recent surge in diagnosed cases in Australia. There are discussions about the factors contributing to its rise and the importance of awareness campaigns, commonly referred to as the 'Gout Race'.

articles.title: Fish Species Vanishing from Drought-Prone Streams Due to Global Warming
articles.author: Ishwi Singh
articles.summary: New research shows that even fish that are used to living in hot and dry areas are having a hard time as the climate gets warmer. The study focused on xeric climates, which are dry and receive little rain throughout the year. In US streams, about two species per stream disappeared over the study period. In Australia, the decline was 0.083 millimetres per year.

articles.title: Heatwave Death Toll: 16,500 in Europe, Study Finds
articles.author: Mirage News
articles.summary: Rapid analysis report of 854 European cities estimates that climate change responsible for over two-thirds of heat deaths this summer. People aged 65 and over made up 85% of the estimated deaths. The study covered cities representing about 30% of Europe's population. Urban areas are particularly at risk. Expanding green spaces could provide critical lifelines.

articles.title: After Helene, some students struggle to get back on track
articles.author: Associated Press
articles.summary: Hurricane Helene damaged more than 73,000 homes in western North Carolina. More than 2,500 students were identified as homeless as a direct result of the storm. The homeless student population surged, doubling in some places and increasing fourfold in one county. Schools reopened long before many students returned to their homes and their learning and well-being have yet to recover.

articles.title: Australia Targets 62–70 Percent Emissions Reduction by 2035
articles.author: Israa Farhan
articles.summary: Australia announced a new climate target to cut greenhouse gas emissions by between 62 and 70 percent below 2005 levels by 2035. Prime Minister Anthony Albanese is expected to present the government's updated climate ambitions at the United Nations General Assembly next week. South Korean actress Kang Seo-ha died at 31 after cancer battle. Spain announce their squad for the 2026 FIFA World Cup qualifiers.

articles.title: Mozambique: Gas is not part of Africa's solution to climate change
articles.author: Chris Engelbrecht
articles.summary: The Mozambican state promotes planned offshore gas projects in the war-torn northern province of Cabo Delgado. The International Court of Justice (ICJ) delivered its groundbreaking advisory opinion on climate change as a human rights concern in July 2025. Mozambique is among the countries most vulnerable to climate change.

articles.title: Burke County, Morganton to premiere documentary on Hurricane Helene heroes and survivors
articles.author: Burke County Government
articles.summary: A documentary premiere will be held on Saturday, Sept. 27, at 10 a.m. at the Catawba River Soccer Complex in Morganton. The event is free and open to the public. Seating, light refreshments and a raffle will be provided.

articles.title: NiMet, Adamawa State University Partner To Boost Climate Research
articles.author: Oluwasola Akintonde
articles.summary: NiMet and Adamawa State University have signed a Memorandum of Understanding to strengthen climate research and enhance the delivery of timely weather warnings. The agreement focuses on improving real-time weather alerts and seasonal forecasts tailored to farmers and communities in Adamawa state. It also supports specialised training programs for students and practitioners, and joint publications on region-specific climate challenges.

articles.title: How did Aboriginal Australians reach Australia?
articles.summary: Aboriginal Australians first arrived on the continent tens of thousands of years ago. They made one of the earliest known sea crossings. Their arrival in Australia marked the beginning of a deep and enduring connection to the land. Click through the gallery to find out how they made the journey.

articles.title: In an unprecedented warning, leading climate think-tank says Canada won't meet 2030 climate target
articles.author: CBC
articles.summary: Canada's progress on cutting carbon emissions has stalled, according to the Canadian Climate Institute. The early 2024 emissions estimate from the institute suggests future progress looks increasingly fragile.       .   in the early 2024s,  in which Canada's carbon emissions are estimated to be at their lowest level since 1970.

articles.title: Letter: Recognize serious threat posed by climate change
articles.summary: Rising temperatures are causing hundreds of thousands to die each year, increasing disease outbreaks, prolonging droughts, shifting rainfall patterns, disrupting ecosystems, worsening food and water shortages, and displacing tens of millions of people. The Pacific Islands Forum listed addressing climate change threats as their top priority.

articles.title: Australia Announces Higher Emissions Cuts By 2035
articles.author: Jide Ibitoye
articles.summary: Australia will aim to cut its carbon emissions by at least 62% compared to 2005 levels over the next decade. The new target is in line with an emission reduction benchmark recommended by the Climate Change Authority. The PM will confirm the commitment at the UN General Assembly in New York later this month.

articles.title: Darkest Nights Are Getting Lighter
articles.summary: Light pollution now doubles every eight years globally as LED adoption accelerates artificial brightness. Northern Chile's Atacama Desert remains one of the few Bortle Scale 1 locations with the darkest rating for artificial brightness, according to a recent study measured 10% annual growth in light pollution from 2011 to 2022.

articles.title: How climate change is fueling your sugar addiction
articles.author: Grist
articles.summary: As climate change warms up the planet, the appeal of sugary treats is getting louder, according to a new study. Rising temperatures do make a difference on what you eat and drink, as well as how much you drink and eat, according the study.

articles.title: Climate chaos: WMO warns of an erratic water cycle
articles.author: Mrityunjay Bose
articles.summary: Many small glaciers have already reached or are about to pass the so-called peak water point. Peak water point is when a glacier's melting reaches its maximum annual runoff. After this, the runoff decreases due to glacier shrinkage and the glacier starts to melt.

articles.title: Climate warriors want to build a curtain in the sea: It's a bad idea
articles.author: Lara Williams
articles.summary: The Arctic warmed nearly four times faster than the rest of the globe between 1979 and 2021. Sea curtains are proposed to keep warm water from reaching the Antarctic and Greenland ice sheets. The Seabed Curtain project envisions an 80km-long structure anchored to the seabed 650m deep with 150m tall curtains. Frontiers in Science highlights the dangers of numerous proposed polar geoengineering methods, including sea curtains.

articles.title: ‘A slap in the face': our expert panel on Australia's 2035 emissions target
articles.author: Anika Molesworth
articles.summary: The government's emissions target of 62-70% is a betrayal to farmers and rural communities. Farmers are already leading with renewable energy, soil carbon projects and regenerative practices. The resources sector plan focuses on decarbonising existing emissions through electrification, using low carbon fuels, and reducing fugitive emissions. The government needs to strengthen its policies and deal with the fossil fuel industry.

articles.title: How vulnerable are Australia's cities to extreme heat? Explore our maps
articles.author: Josh Nicholas
articles.summary: The data obtained exclusively by Guardian Australia shows the parts of Australia's major cities that are most vulnerable to heat. The data shows particularly high vulnerability in western Sydney and the outer suburbs of Melbourne, Adelaide and most other major Australian cities, but also in colder climates like Hobart, Launceston and Albury. Monash University found heatwaves caused 1,009 deaths in Australia between 2016 and 2019.

articles.title: ‘There's a complete credibility gap': Labor's climate targets analysed
articles.summary: Aidan Morrison analyses Labor's climate targets and the missing costings from the paperwork. Aidan Morrison also questions the Albanese government's constant reiteration that Australia is way above the rest of the world in terms of its ambition.

articles.title: UN warns climate change causing havoc with global water cycle as EU to settle on emissions plan
articles.author: AFP
articles.summary: Last year was the hottest on record, leading to prolonged droughts in northern parts of South America, the Amazon Basin and southern Africa. Europe and Asia were hit with wetter weather than usual, being hit with devastating floods or deadly storms. Last year was sixth consecutive year where there had been a clear imbalance in the world's river basins. Water quality in major lakes was declining and glaciers shrank across all regions for the third year in a row.

articles.title: Why Alaska's salmon streams are suddenly bleeding orange
articles.author: Science Daily
articles.summary: Warming Arctic permafrost is unlocking toxic metals, turning Alaska's once-clear rivers into orange. The rivers are fed by the warm, melting permafrosts, which are turning the rivers orange.      Â   .

articles.title: Australia's Net Migration Rate Falls to Over 300,000 New Arrivals
articles.author: The Epoch Times
articles.summary: Australia's population grew by 423,400 people in the year to March 2025 to 27.5 million. The growth has slowed as overseas migration continues to fall. The Treasury forecast for net overseas migration is now 17,000 people lower than the actual growth. It is 40 percent below the peak after COVID.

articles.title: Climate change wreaking havoc on world's water cycle: UN
articles.summary: Last year's record heat led to prolonged droughts and extreme floods across the globe. Climate change is wreaking havoc on the world's water cycle, according to UN report.       .   "Last year s record heat and extreme flooding were caused by climate change."

articles.title: New emission targets mean climate wars may be turning a corner
articles.author: The AFR View
articles.summary: Labor's decision to lift its emissions reduction goal to a target range of 62% to 70% over 2005 levels by 2035 is sensible. Climate Change and Energy Minister Chris Bowen declared that a national target above 70% is unachievable. Australia's long and tortured 'climate wars' may be entering a more pragmatic phase.

articles.title: Global Water Cycle Turns Unstable With Intensifying Floods, Droughts: WMO
articles.author: BW Online Bureau
articles.summary: The world is witnessing an erratic water cycle, with sharp swings between drought and floods. Last year was the hottest on record and the third consecutive year of widespread glacier loss. South America and southern Africa were hit by prolonged drought, while regions of Africa, Asia and Europe suffered repeated flooding.

articles.title: Climate change causing havoc with global water cycle: UN
articles.author: AFP
articles.summary: Climate change is spurring extreme swings between deluge and drought across the world. Last year was the hottest on record, leading to prolonged droughts in northern parts of South America, the Amazon Basin and southern Africa. Europe and Asia were hit with wetter weather than usual, being hit with devastating floods or deadly storms. There was a clear imbalance in the world's river basins last year.

articles.title: Albanese's Oprah-style emissions target aims to please almost everyone but falls short of real climate action
articles.author: Adam Morton
articles.summary: The Australian government has announced an emissions target for 2035. The minimum target is 62%, which is well below what scientists say Australia should do to play its part in keeping alive the goals agreed as part of the 2015 Paris agreement. The authority assumes that renewable energy will continue to surge and provide up to 93% of electricity by 2035, but it has taken a conservative approach in assessing what would be possible across the economy.

articles.title: Climate change wreaking havoc on world's water cycle: UN
articles.author: Mariamne Everett
articles.summary: Climate change is making the Earth's water cycle erratic, resulting in extreme swings between deluge and drought. Last year was the hottest on record, leading to prolonged droughts in northern parts of South America, the Amazon Basin and Southern Africa. 2024 was the sixth consecutive year where there had been a clear imbalance in the world's river basins, with two-thirds of them having too much or too little water.

articles.title: ‘We will just be poorer': Albanese's emissions reduction targets labelled ‘madness'
articles.summary: Sky News host Chris Kenny discusses Prime Minister Anthony Albanese's emissions reduction targets for 2035. Mr Kenny believes the climate will not be any better or worse than it was going to be anyway, despite billions of dollars spent and all the power bills going up.

articles.title: Australia raises 'climate ambition goal', pledges 62–70% emissions cut by 2035
articles.author: ...Read More
articles.summary: Australia has announced plans to slash its carbon emissions by at least 62% compared to 2005 levels within the next decade. The new goal marks a sharp increase from its earlier pledge of a 43% cut by 2030. Meeting the new target forms part of Australia's commitment under the Paris Climate Agreement.

articles.title: Europe's Deadly Summer: 16,500 Deaths Linked to Climate Change
articles.author: Ishwi Singh
articles.summary: This summer was Europe's fourth-hottest on record. About 70% of the deaths were directly connected to climate change. Rome had the highest number of heat-related deaths, followed by Athens and Paris. The elderly are most at risk during extreme heat. Scientists warn that heatwaves will become more intense.

articles.title: Australia unveils 2035 emissions target, drawing environmental criticism
articles.author: Invezz
articles.summary: Australia announced on Thursday its 2035 emissions target aiming for a 62-70% reduction from 2005 levels. This figure was lower than anticipated and drew criticism from environmental organisations. Albanese government's new climate plan is an affront to communities across the Pacific and Australia.

articles.title: 'We are part of a global transformation': Australia unveils new national climate action plan
articles.author: Steve Butterworth
articles.summary: Australia has announced a new national climate action plan ahead of the COP30 UN Climate Summit in Brazil in November. It confirms a new target to cut emissions by between between 1.5 and 2.5% by 2030.   iStock photo shows the old and new parliament houses of Australia.

articles.title: Himachal Pradesh Himalayan Temperature Rises 0.9°C Warns Scientist
articles.author: ANI
articles.summary: The average temperature in the Himalayan region of Himachal Pradesh has risen by 0.9°C. The warming trend could reach 2-2.5°C by the end of the century if unchecked. The monsoon season has been unusually long this year. The cycle of Western Disturbances has been disturbed due to global warming. There is a need for Long-term Climate-Resilient Planning in the state.

articles.title: Plans for juice factory, crop diversification at Skeldon
articles.author: GTIMES
articles.summary: President Dr Mohamed Irfaan Ali is addressing private cane farmers in Skeldon, Berbice, Region Six (East Berbice-Corentyne).    He will address them on behalf of the President.   .

articles.title: 2026 Skoda Enyaq review
articles.summary: Hard slog ahead for Australia to reach new climate target, according to the report.      Â   - Analysis and analysis.  - Report and Analysis  - Research  - Review  -   Report and Review   –

articles.title: 2026 Skoda Enyaq: Model Y rival now $20,000 cheaper
articles.summary: Hard slog ahead for Australia to reach new climate target, according to the report.      Â   - Analysis of the Report on Australia’s New Climate Targets.  - Report on the Report: Australia's New climate targets.

articles.title: Keep up With the Science: Professor Says Climate Risk Assessment Must Be Regular
articles.author: The Epoch Times
articles.summary: Monash University professor proposes Australia's national Climate Risk Assessment should be conducted regularly to stay relevant amid rapidly evolving climate science. On Sept. 15, the Labor government unveiled the first national climate risk assessment.       in response to the September 15th announcement.

articles.title: Forest fire still high in 2025 despite wetter dry season
articles.author: Gembong Hanung
articles.summary: Indonesia is experiencing a wet dry season with relatively high rainfalls. There is an increasing rate of forest and land fires across the country, particularly in oil palm plantation and energy concessions. Almost 100,000 ha were engulfed by fire in July alone, nearly twice the area burned in July 2023.

articles.title: Study finds almost 25,000 deaths in Europe caused by climate change
articles.author: Web Desk
articles.summary: There were 24,400 heat deaths in 854 European cities this summer due to climate change. The deadliest heatwave was experienced by Romania, Bulgaria, Greece and Cyprus from July 21-27, 2025, resulting in the death of 950 people. 85% of the total heat deaths were among people aged above 65.

articles.title: Ghana Female Oyster Farmers Sustain Tradition Amid Climate and Aid Challenges
articles.summary: Beatrice Nutekpor harvests oysters daily in the Tsokomey community near Accra. This practice faces threats from dynamic water conditions and mangrove loss. The Densu Oyster Pickers Association enforces guidelines with penalties for cutting mangroves outside allowed periods to protect oyster habitats.

articles.title: ‘It's not just our houses': can a Scottish village save Queen Elizabeth's coastal path from ...
articles.author: The Guardian
articles.summary: The people of Johnshaven have watched the sea edge getting closer and closer. Preserving the path is key to protecting their community. The gardens that were there and now they're gone, so the people need to preserve the path to prevent their community from being destroyed.

articles.title: Climate inaction would cost economy at least $1.2 trillion: Treasury
articles.author: Australian Financial Review
articles.summary: Jim Chalmers says taking action on climate change is a 'golden economic opportunity' for Australia. Inaction will cost Australia at least $1.2 trillion by 2050, he says.    - by 2050 Australia will be worth $2 trillion less.

articles.title: Australia pledges to cut up to 70% emissions by 2035
articles.author: Aryan Rai
articles.summary: Australia pledges to slash greenhouse gas emissions by 62 to 70 per cent from 2005 levels over the next decade. Australia's goals are above those of Canada and neighbouring New Zealand, but below the United Kingdom which is one of the most ambitious in the world. The Climate Change Authority warned the world was on track for 2.9C of warming this century.

articles.title: A step up in action to hit the 2035 emissions target is urgently needed
articles.author: Tony Wood
articles.summary: Australia is committed to reducing its greenhouse gas emissions by 62-to-70 per cent below the 2005 level by 2035 as part of its obligations under the 2016 Paris Agreement and its commitment to containing global warming. The 2035 emissions-reduction target is ambitious but credible and achievable.

articles.title: Australia targets at least 62% emissions cut in the next decade
articles.author: Killeen Daily Herald
articles.summary: Australia has set a new target of reducing its greenhouse gas emissions by between 62% and 70% below 2005 levels by 2035. The new target adds to Australia's ambition of a 43% cut by the end of this year and adds to its previous target of 43%.

articles.title: Earth could lose its precious coral reefs if planet warms by 2 degrees Celsius
articles.author: Aryan Rai
articles.summary: Coral reefs around the world could soon stop growing and gradually erode as a result of climate change, according to a new study in Nature. 70% of the regions' reefs could stop growing by 2040 and 99% by 2100. Coral reefs support a quarter of all marine life despite taking up a mere 1% of ocean floor.

articles.title: Australia's Net Migration Rate Falls to Over 300,000 New Arrivals
articles.author: Naziya Alvi Rahman
articles.summary: Australia's population grew overall by 423,400 people in the year to March 2025, reaching 27.5 million. Net migration was 315,900 people, down from 493,800 in the previous year, according to the Australian Bureau of Statistics figures.

articles.title: Water cycle becoming harder to predict: UN scientists
articles.author: Rebecca Speare-Cole
articles.summary: 2023 will be the most negative year for ice loss, followed by 2024 with 450 gigatonnes of loss. There were some positive years for ice in the 1980s, but now the world is seeing more negative years. The most negative years are 2023, 2024 and 2029.

articles.title: Water cycle becoming harder to predict: UN scientists
articles.author: Rebecca Speare-Cole
articles.summary: Last year was the sixth in a row to show an erratic cycle and the third where all glacier regions reported ice loss, according to the World Meteorological Organisation's (WMO) state of global water resources report for 2024. 2024 was generally a dry and hot year, featuring record-breaking temperatures driven by the warming El Nino weather phenomenon. 60 per cent of rivers globally showed either too much or too little water compared to the average flow per year. Only a third of river basins globally had normal discharge levels.

articles.title: Water cycle becoming harder to predict: UN scientists
articles.author: Rebecca Speare-Cole
articles.summary: Earth's water cycle is becoming harder to predict as the climate changes, UN scientists have warned.       "The future of the world's water supply is uncertain"   'The future direction of the climate is uncertain'  "It's impossible to predict the future direction".

articles.title: Water cycle becoming harder to predict: UN scientists
articles.author: Rebecca Speare-Cole
articles.summary: Last year was the sixth in a row to show an erratic cycle and the third where all glacier regions reported ice loss. In 2024, only a third of river basins globally were found to have normal discharge levels, with most seeing too much or too little water flowing out to sea.

articles.title: Australia targets 62% to 70% emissions cut by 2035
articles.author: TDT News
articles.summary: Australia has set a new target of reducing its greenhouse gas emissions by between 62% and 70% below 2005 levels by 2035. The new target adds to Australia's ambition of a 43% cut by the end of this year and adds to its previous target of 43%.

articles.title: Australia targets 62% to 70% emissions cut by 2035
articles.author: Rod McGuirk
articles.summary: Australia set a new target of reducing its greenhouse gas emissions by between 62% and 70% below 2005 levels by 2035. Prime Minister Anthony Albanese will take his government's 2035 target to the United Nations General Assembly next week. Under the Paris climate agreement, nations must increase their emissions reduction targets every five years.

articles.title: Australia sets ambitious 2035 climate target and pledges billions for clean energy
articles.author: Reuters
articles.summary: Australia has pledged to reduce its greenhouse gas emissions by 62-70 per cent over the next decade. The announcement comes ahead of a UN deadline for governments to submit their updated climate plans before the Cop30 summit in Brazil this November. Australia is one of the world's highest emitters per capita.

articles.title: Global water cycle ‘erratic' in 2024, leading to floods, drought
articles.summary: Temperatures in 2024 were 1.55C above the pre-industrial average, which is the highest in 175 years. Last year almost two-thirds of global river basins had water levels either significantly above or significantly below normal values. The Amazon basin and west and central Africa were the worst-hit regions in 2024, where flooding killed 2,500 people and displaced 4 million.

articles.title: On the move
articles.summary: Canada geese take flight at Saltese Flats in this Sept. 2 photo by Terry Sanborn. Submit your own outdoors-related photographs for a chance to be published in our weekly print edition. Browse our archive of past reader submissions online at spokesman.com/outdoors.

articles.title: Labor's 2035 greenhouse targets: Inadequate and ‘greenwashing'
articles.summary: The Labor government's 2035 greenhouse gas emission reduction target of 62-70% is not enough to limit global warming to 1.5°C. Australia is the world's third-largest fossil fuel exporter, after Russia and the U.S. It is also the second-largest exporter of fossil fuel carbon dioxide emissions. The new measures that Labor proposes to meet its new 2035 target mostly amount to subsidies and grants to private corporations.

articles.title: Nearly 6 crore Bangladeshis endured risky heat this summer
articles.author: Star Online Report
articles.summary: Nearly six crore people in Bangladesh endured over 30 days of dangerous heat between June and August this year. Climate Central report highlights Bangladesh as one of the ten worst-affected countries worldwide. The report warns of long-term consequences for public health, food security, water resources, and the economy if temperatures continue to climb.

articles.title: Climate scientists had a savage verdict for Australia's target, but the government is standing firm
articles.author: Nick O'Malley
articles.summary: The government announced a new emission reduction target of 62 to 70 per cent on 2005 levels by 2035. Climate scientists are not satisfied with the new target. Chris Bowen is unrepentant that the target must be ambitious and achievable. The tension between what is necessary and what is possible is growing because so much warming is now inevitable.

articles.title: Climate scientists had a savage verdict for Australia's target, but the government is standing firm
articles.author: Nick O'Malley
articles.summary: The government announced a new emission reduction target of 62 to 70 per cent on 2005 levels by 2035. Bill Hare, one of the founders of the non-governmental policy institute Climate Analytics, said the new target is worse than he feared. He said it is necessary for Australia to align with the goal of holding warming to close to 1.5 degrees.

articles.title: Climate Change Hits Homes: Heat, Air, Insurance Impact
articles.author: Mirage News
articles.summary: This year, extreme heat in Europe killed roughly 2,300 people, severe flooding on the New South Wales coast left more than 48,000 stranded and wildfires in Los Angeles destroyed at least 16,000 homes and other buildings. Australia's first National Climate Risk Assessment estimates 8.7% of residential buildings are in very high-risk areas (prone to hazards). This proportion is projected to increase to 13.5% by 2090 in a scenario with a high global warming level. Climate change can compromise air quality by making building materials more likely to degrade and generate pollutants. It can also influence housing security and affordability.

articles.title: Labor's 2035 emissions target; ABC barred from Trump's UK press conference; and a blackbird's message
articles.author: Alan Vaarwerk
articles.summary: Australia will aim to cut greenhouse gas emissions by between 62% and 70% of 2005 levels by 2035 under the federal government's new climate target. Sally Faulkner has been reunited with her children after a decade of separation. Alan Jones pleads not guilty to 27 charges after number of alleged victims drops from 11 to nine. No more forced job cuts at Australian National University, but $250m restructure to continue. $30bn Santos takeover collapses after Abu Dhabi consortium withdraws offer. Chappell Roan leads lineup at Laneway festival 2026.

articles.title: Weatherwatch: Early ripening berries could be bad news for UK's visiting birds
articles.author: The Guardian
articles.summary: The warmest summer on record has brought a premature autumn. This could leave little food for overwintering birds, which is bad news for them.      Â   yestlke. yestlk.com

articles.title: Labor's 'defensible' plan could be its biggest miscalculation
articles.author: Mark Kenny
articles.summary: Labor has a long-delayed 2035 emissions reduction target of 62 per cent on 2005 emissions. The government accepts that the real pace of economic and social transformation needs to step up in heavily polluting sectors of the economy. There are new funds to incentivise decarbonisation in industry, accelerate electrification and drive energy efficiency.

articles.summary: 2035 emissions reduction target for Labor is 62 per cent. The government accepts that the real pace of economic and social transformation needs to step up in heavily polluting sectors of the economy. There are new funds to incentivise decarbonisation in industry, accelerate electrification and drive energy efficiency.

articles.title: Timid or too tough? Verdicts in on emissions target
articles.author: Tess Ikonomou
articles.summary: Efforts to reduce Australia's greenhouse gas emissions during the next decade are being criticised as either too ambitious or not going far enough.   in terms of going too far enough or too ambitious.  for going too ambitious  for not going further enough.

articles.title: Floods devastate 1.3 million acres of crops in Punjab
articles.summary: Flooding in Punjab province has caused massive damage to agriculture, wiping out key crops and threatening food security across Pakistan. Around 1.329 million acres of farmland have been affected, about 6.3% of the province's cultivated area. Floods were triggered by torrential rains and flash floods. Rice fields bore the heaviest blow, with 654,000 acres submerged. Fodder and maize crops were the next hardest hit, while sesame, sugarcane, and cotton also suffered significant damage.

articles.title: New Soil Warming Study Challenges Climate Change Predictions

articles.summary: Warming the soil does not always lead to increased CO2 emissions. Instead, higher emissions occur when there is more carbon, nutrients and phosphorous in the soil. Soil contains living organisms such as bacteria, fungi, viruses and others that release carbon dioxide through their metabolic processes. Microbes need both energy and nutrients to grow and release more carbon dioxide when temperatures increase.

articles.title: Coral Reefs' Growth Halts With Warming Climate
articles.author: Mirage News
articles.summary: Most coral reefs in the western Atlantic will stop growing by 2040 and almost all will do so by 2100 if global warming hits 2°C, according to a new study by scientists from the University of Exeter. They assessed 400 reef sites around Florida, Mexico and Bonaire. Climate change, disease and deteriorating water quality kill corals and impact colony growth rates.

articles.title: Labor's Climate Target Misaligned, Needs Fossil Phase-Out
articles.author: Mirage News
articles.summary: The process of extracting and shipping all the coal and gas Australia exports is responsible for close to 18% of Australia's total emissions. Pacific leaders warned Australia the decision to extend the North West Shelf extension could breach a landmark International Court of Justice ruling on the responsibility states have to address climate change.

articles.title: Human-caused climate change drove up unusual summer heat, report finds
articles.author: CBS News
articles.summary: Human-caused climate change drove up risky and unnatural heat for nearly 2 billion people this summer, according to a new report from Climate Central. CBS News national environmental correspondent David Schechter explains it to Climate Central's David Schachter on "This is Life on Earth".

articles.title: Labor's Climate Target Failure: Win for Coal, Gas
articles.author: Mirage News
articles.summary: Labor's climate target of 62% reduction by 2035 is a betrayal of people and the planet. The Climate Risk Report outlines the devastating risks this target raises for Australia. 1.5 million Australians are at risk of sea level rise, rolling disastrous weather events, surging heat deaths and mass extinction.

articles.title: Human-caused climate change drove up unusual summer heat, report finds

articles.title: Sherry for moving BISP support to flood-hit people
articles.author: Asim Yasin
articles.summary: Sherry Rehman, the chairperson of the Senate Standing Committee on Climate Change, called on the government to provide BISP support to flood-impacted people. The committee ordered the immediate mapping of Pakistan's waterways and blockages on the floodplains of the Indus River and its tributaries, as well as water storage options that are affordable and impactful based on best practices everywhere. 998 people lost their lives and 1,062 were injured in the current wave of floods.

articles.title: WWF Warns Australia's Emissions Target Risks Climate
articles.author: Mirage News
articles.summary: Prime Minister Anthony Albanese has set a 2035 emissions reduction target of 62-70% for Australia. WWF-Australia CEO Dermot O'Gorman says the target falls short of what the science demands. He urges the government to stop approving new fossil fuel projects and end deforestation.

articles.title: Weak Emissions Target Endangers Vulnerable Populations
articles.author: Mirage News
articles.summary: ACOSS and the community sector called for a science-based and fair share emissions reduction target of net zero (100%) by 2035. ACOSS is calling on the Federal government to commit to a plan to change the target at the international climate negotiations in November.

articles.title: National Academy of Sciences dismisses EPA
articles.author: Sioux City Journal
articles.summary: Evidence that climate change harms public health is "beyond scientific dispute," according to the WHO. The agency's director says there is no scientific evidence to support this claim, however, so it's still not scientifically settled.      Â

articles.title: ABC News Breakfast With Bridget Brennan 18 September
articles.author: Mirage News
articles.summary: Indigenous Affairs Minister Malarndirri McCarthy is in Alice Springs. Bridget Brennan is visiting the Torres Straits Islands. They are concerned about climate change and sea level rises. The government has committed over $30 million for the seawalls for stage three. The Queensland Government will work with them on this.

articles.title: Albanese Govt Prioritizes Coal Over Safety, Nature
articles.author: Mirage News
articles.summary: The Albanese government has set a target to reduce emissions by 62-70% by 2035. Gavan McFadzean, the Australian Conservation Foundation's climate and energy program manager, says the target range is too low. He claims the government is in thrall to the coal and gas industry and ignores the worst-case scenarios in the National Climate Risk Assessment.

articles.title: Albanese Govt Prioritizes Coal, Gas Over Safety, Nature
articles.author: Mirage News
articles.summary: The Albanese government has set a target to reduce emissions by 62–70% by 2035. The Australian Conservation Foundation's climate and energy program manager Gavan McFadzean is critical of the target range. He believes the government is more committed to the future of the coal and gas industry than to the safety of Australian communities and nature.

articles.title: Australia's Climate Threatens Health, Life
articles.author: Mirage News
articles.summary: CAHA is warning the Australian Government it's time to get serious on climate action. CAHA's Vice President and practising general practitioner, Dr Catherine Pendrey, says the health system is already stretched and not prepared for the extreme challenges posed by climate change. She wants the government to set its 2035 climate target as close to net zero as possible and stop approving new coal, oil and gas developments.

articles.title: A home on the North Carolina coast collapses, 12th incident in five years
articles.author: WRAL
articles.summary: Another vacant home has fallen into the ocean on the North Carolina coast. This is the 12th such incident in five years. WRAL News shares what homeowners can do to prevent their house becoming the next victim.       .  Â

articles.title: 2035 Targets Advice Report Released
articles.author: Mirage News
articles.summary: The Climate Change Authority recommends Australia set a 2035 target to reduce the nation's greenhouse gas emissions by 62-70% compared with 2005 levels. On a per-capita basis, the target equates to a 76-81% reduction once projected population growth over the coming decade is included.

articles.title: Greenpeace: Climate Target Favors Fossil Fuel Profits
articles.author: Mirage News
articles.summary: Greenpeace Australia Pacific is critical of the Albanese government's new climate target for 2035. Greenpeace says the new climate plan is not science-aligned and undermines global action under the Paris Agreement to limit warming to 1.5C. Greenpeace also points to the recent landmark, Pacific-led victory at the International Court of Justice that ruled under international law that states are obligated to align their climate plans with the target.

articles.title: Australia Vs India Vs China – The great climate change debate
articles.author: Tarric Brooker
articles.summary: The Australian Climate Service has published its latest National Risk Assessment on the potential impact of climate change on the nation. The report modelled scenarios in which global temperatures rose between 1.5°C and 3°C above pre-industrial levels out to 2050 and 2100. The risks to communities, the economy, and property are 'severe' or 'very high'.

articles.title: Horn of Africa forecast to experience dry weather until December
articles.author: China.dot.org
articles.summary: The Horn of Africa is forecast to experience drier-than-usual conditions from October to December. Dryer conditions are expected over most parts of Somalia, Djibouti, coastal Sudan and Eritrea, southern Ethiopia, Kenya, and central to southern Uganda and Tanzania.

articles.title: Emissions from wildfires highest in 23 years
articles.author: RTE
articles.summary: Blazes across Europe this summer caused the continent's largest recorded wildfire carbon emissions in nearly a quarter-century, according to EU climate monitor Copernicus. The emissions from these wildfires have been the largest for any summer in at least the last 23 years.

articles.title: Climate change wreaking havoc on world's water cycle: UN
articles.author: Al Jazeera
articles.summary: Climate change is making the Earth's water cycle erratic, according to the UN's World Meteorological Organization. The world's water resources are under growing pressure and more extreme water-related hazards are having an increasing impact on lives and livelihoods, the WMO warned.

articles.title: No quick fix for melting ice: UMass scientists say geoengineering proposals are costly ‘band-aids'
articles.author: Daily Hampshire Gazette
articles.summary: Two UMass scientists have joined 42 other international polar experts to warn against the inefficiencies and dangers of engineering in extreme cold environments as a way to slow global warming in lieu of alternative methods of energy production and control climate change. They are concerned about icebergs floating in the sea near Kulusuk, Greenland.

articles.title: Forest fire still high in 2025 despite wetter dry season
articles.author: The Jakarta Post
articles.summary: Indonesia is experiencing a 'wet dry season' with relatively high rainfalls. There is an increasing rate of forest and land fires across the country, particularly in oil palm plantation and energy concessions, according to an independent analysis launched by Jakarta-based agency.

articles.author: Forbes
articles.summary: These five individuals are focused on climate-related impact in their local communities, from the cloud forests of the Andes to the deserts of Egypt, and they are concerned about their communities' climate change impact.    .     Â

articles.title: Why does Charleston flood so often, and sometimes so much?
articles.author: Gavin McIntyre/Staff
articles.summary: Charleston, South Carolina, is experiencing regular nuisance flooding because of sea-level rise caused by climate change. The peninsula's west side is currently 13 feet above sea level, while the peninsula's east side is 60 feet. The average elevation of the peninsula is perhaps 8 feet, but a third of all residential properties are located on land that is 10 feet or less above the sea level.
